The epic beat-down of stocks is creating some epic buying opportunities. 
There are nine stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500, including American Airlines (AAL) , General Motors (GM) and diversified energy equipment company FMC Technologies (FTI) that have been battered so badly by the market meltdown they appear now be buying opportunities, according to a USA TODAY analysis of data from S&P Capital IQ and market research firm New Constructs. 
Each of these stocks have fallen a crushing 20% or more from their highs - putting them into bear markets. But this pain is opens the door for potential gains. Each of the stocks are expected to be worth 20% or more in 18 months, rated "outperform" or "buy" by Wall Street analysts, get a perfect 5-star stock rating from S&P Capital and are rated "neutral" or better by market research firm New Constructs . Just 45 stocks in the S&P 500 currently get S&P Capital IQ's top rating. 
With the market in full-fledged rally mode, investors are picking through the carnage looking to profit from other investors' collective freak out moment. The S&P 500 had lost 12.4% of its value at the closing low this week on Tuesday - but has since staged an impressive 5.9% rally from those lows. Investors on Wednesday alone profited $682 billion in a single day - which has been the most powerful yet in the rebound. Stock rebound gains speed: Dow rallies 300+ 
The biggest potential winner in the eyes of investors is airline American Airlines. American, along with the other airlines, has seen its shares get absolutely demolished since peaking in March. Shares are down 31% from from their 52-week high of $56.20 a share and trading at $38.55 Thursday. 
Stocks in the airline industry were first to suffer even before the market as a whole cracked. American's shares are down 8.4% from the broad S&P 500's peak on May 21. But given low energy prices and constrained capacity, analysts still think American is a winner. Analysts are calling for American to be worth $56.20 a share in 18 months, if correct, would be a 41% gain - or the biggest upside among these beat-up stocks. Shares also get "attractive" rating by New Constructs, which compares stock prices to the present value of expected future cash flows. 
An American Airlines jet makes its landing approach at Los Angeles International Airport. (Photo: Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY) 
Investors looking for stocks to take advantage of the market's most recent selloff might also look at FMC Technologies. The company that sells gear to energy companies has lost a quarter of its value since the market's top in May - more than any another of these stocks that analysts see upside in. It's also about down a bruising 50% down from its high over the past 52-weeks, trading Thursday at $32 a share. Yet, analysts think this stock should be worth 24% higher in 18 months with a price target of $39.76 a share. 
Both the big U.S. automakers are also big opportunities for investors, according to analysts. General Motors and Ford (F) shares are down 27% and 25% respectively from their highest points over the past year - putting them both well within bear market territory. But analysts see 40% potential upside in GM shares and 31% upside in Ford. New Constructs rates GM "attractive" and Ford "neutral." Wall Street analysts rate both stocks "outperform." Shares of GM are up 2% today to $28.70 and Ford shares are up 3% to $13.57. 
The recent recovery in stock prices could prove to just be a fleeting bounce. That remains to be seen. But investors buying stocks that are already down 20% - but still highly rated - can at least feel good about taking advantage of the pain - rather than being one of the investors who panicked.
